article_text:
The "Dying Gaul" is alive and well in Washington, D.C., having left Rome earlier this week for the first time in centuries to go on exhibit at the National Gallery of Art—an icon of antiquity once coveted by everyone from Nero to Napoleon and on public view until March 16.

The National Gallery expects record-level crowds to line up for this one-man show, "The Dying Gaul: An Ancient Roman Masterpiece from the Capitoline Museum, Rome"—in part because this roughly 2,000-year-old marble figure of a fatally...

twitter.description: Leaving Italy for the first time in nearly 200 years, "The Dying Gaul," a touchstone of art history, will be on view at Washington's National Gallery of Art through early March.

The "Dying Gaul" is alive and well in Washington, D.C., having left Rome earlier this week for the first time in centuries to go on exhibit at the National Gallery of Art—an icon of antiquity once coveted by everyone from Nero to Napoleon and on public view until March 16.
